posts.title: Storing Images on a Server
posts.short-description: The way to go about uploading and storing images on a database (without making it ridiculously slow) for later use.

content.content_text:
Many new programmers face, at some point, the challenge of uploading images to a server and as me they immediately think of just uploading the image to the database as a blob and that's it, job DONE.
Well I learnt my mistake a few years ago and I'm here to teach you a new and improved way of doing it, the way I use on my projects.

content_alert.message: This post is just a walkthrough how you should do it and not a programming tutorial, I will eventually have a post on how to upload to database with kotlin and ktor.

content.content_text: Well as you might have guessed we would store them in the filesystem of the server instead of the database. After storing it on the filesystem you just grab the path to the image and insert it to the database. Whenever you need the image you would just get the path and load it from there.

This seems like a hard concept to grasp because then we leave the app with two different components that work together to have a full functionality, the upload to the filesystem and the insert on the database.
Here comes the flow of the program, what I usually do is when the user chooses a image from his phone or pc the program starts the upload while the user keeps doing other things (like inputing username, password, etc..) and when it's done everything should just go smoothly.

A frequent "error" with this approach is that if a user decides to cancel what your app does while the app is uploading the image you end up with a lost image on your server for no use.
Something you can do is just coding a script that cleans the server once in a while for images with no use.

posts.title: Hosting on github
posts.short-description: Many of us programmers enjoy doing our own little projects to ourselves and sometimes we just need to host these projects somewhere, here's how.

content.content_text:
Pages is a service to host static websites that use HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files straight from your repository on GitHub. Technically we are not able to create dynamic websites but with a little bit of magic hands we are able to do it.

In the next few paragraphs you will learn how to host dynamic websites on github pages for free. You won't need anything like SQL or PHP, the only technologies used here is pure HTML, CSS, JavaScript and JSON.

content_alert.message: In my experience pages should only be used in case of a small easy maintainable website due to the data being stored on a json file.

content.content_text: As you normally do create a new repository. Give it the name you want and make it private or public. Upload an index.html page just to initiate the repository. Once created and uploaded go to settings on the side menu you will find Pages, after this you'll find the following dropdown, choose the same values and save.

content_alert.message:
Your website will be hosted in a similar url:
https://your-username.github.io/repositoryName

In this example you are able to see a todo object with an id, a date and a message. We will use these three properties to show how you can build your website.

posts.title: A letter to first year students
posts.short-description: Sometimes we say and hear that we wanted to do things differently, would you actually do it differently? Well I know it's impossible so I just have to learn from the past.

content.content_text: I know you just got to university youngling but do not despair, it's not as a monster as people make it to be. A year ago when I was in your shoes I also thought that I would be crushed by assignments and kept having that little pea under the mattress saying "you're not smart enough for this" but that was not what happened. And believe me when I say that you will feel the same by the end of your first year!

Well first of all is not a big scary monster, yes sometimes it's a lot of work, yes sometimes you get hard topics on a few modules. But honestly it's quite manageable if you are someone that gets on top of things with time. I'm not going to lie, if you only start doing assignments and work a few days before there's not much to say, you're f****d but if you start doing it with time you'll get it done easy. At least with first year modules you won't have mad 24/7 studying sessions. Yes sometimes you will feel that you have too much work or too many exams but the fear of doing it it's actually harder than the actually studying.

Should you still be worried? Well.... Yes it's still university modules, the right question is Should you still be afraid to fail? NO, because you will be able to do this if you put in the time needed. It's all about time management.

posts.title: Student Talks
posts.short-description: This is the first post on this blog, just a simple  "Get to know us", a welcoming for every person. I hope you can find the posts interesting and easy to follow. Welcome to Student Talks

content.content_text: My name is João Garrido and im currently a second year computer science student at the University of Liverpool, with this blog I want to give everyone reading a way to see the world of programming and technology through the eyes of a student and the eyes of someone who hasn't started the "real" life yet.

I started coding 5 years ago when I started secondary school in Portugal and throughout those three years I learnt a lot, mainly about web development and desktop development with c#. I created a few small projects but my main knowledge of programming came from searching for myself to find what I loved to do. I ended up falling in love with kotlin on my third year, when we had to create a big project that showed our programming capabilities and for 1 month I kept searching what to use and ended up using Kotlin with android to develop an app for vegan and vegetarian recipes, happy to say that app provided me with the highest grade possible! Now I'm just student trying to improve my knowledge of programming.

The very first time I thought about doing something like this was around 6 months ago but I was always thinking, - Who's gonna read what I have to write? Well here I am, although I might not be a FAANG developer or have a youtube page or even not have 20 years of experience in coding but I'm gonna give all my knowledge to everyone who's able to read this blog. Once again Welcome to Student Talks.
